ai_page.body:
Permitted development rights

You can perform certain types of work without needing to apply for planning permission (known as "permitted development rights.").

Detailed information about permitted development rights is available on the Planning Portal and at GOV.UK. In certain circumstances the Council is able to withdraw Permitted Development Rights in a given location (known as Article 4 Directions). You will normally be made aware of their existence if you are buying a property.

Permitted development rights have been withdrawn in the following areas:

  • Fifield, Bray Parish - land either side of Fifield Lane. Article 4’s apply to means of enclosure and access (Class II) and agricultural buildings (Class VI).
  • New Lodge Estate, Drift Road, Bray Parish - land to West of Braywood House. Applies to agricultural buildings (Class VI).
  • The Moorings 1 and 2, Temple, Bisham - two separate Article 4’s on North side of Temple Lane, on bank of Thames near junction with Bradenham Lane, Temple near Bisham. The first relates to the erection or placing of tents for a period of not more than 28 days in total in any one calendar year. The second relates to the erection of gates, fences, walls or other means of enclosure not exceeding one metre (1m) in height where abutting on a highway used by vehicular traffic or two metres (2m) in height in any other case and the maintenance, improvement or other alteration of any gates, fences, walls or other means of enclosure so long as such improvement or alteration does not increase the height above the height appropriate for a new means of enclosure.
  • Bisham - land at Pound Meadow, Temple Lane, Bisham. Relates to the erection, construction, maintenance, improvement or alteration of a gate, wall or other means of enclosure.
  • Windsor Town Centre - planning approval is required for the exterior painting of buildings within the area defined, in order to preserve and enhance the overall appearance of the buildings within the historic town centre.
  • Wraysbury Embankment - related to the erection or construction of gates, fences, walls or other means of enclosure.
  • Wraysbury, Horton and Datchet Parishes - relates to the use of any land as a site for a moveable structure or caravan and the erection or placing of moveable structures and caravans on the land in connection with that use.
  • Chobham Common, Sunningdale - restriction on the use of land for the stationing of caravans (otherwise than for the purposes of a traveling show) on not more than 28 days in total in any calendar year.
  • Bray Conservation Area – planning approval is required for most minor development to front elevations. This is applicable to certain defined properties in order to preserve and enhance the character and appearance of the Conservation Area.
  • Waltham St Lawrence, East of Shurlock Road - related to the erection or construction of gates, fences, walls or other means of enclosure.
  • Article 4 Direction relating to removal of permitted development rights to change of use from Class E (commercial class) to C3 (residential) - any proposal for development specified in the direction, within the protected employment areas set out in BLP Policy ED2, will require planning permission.

For further information, please contact us:

  • Email: planning@rbwm.gov.uk
  • Address:
    Planning Services
    Royal Borough of Windsor and Maidenhead
    Town Hall
    St Ives Road
    Maidenhead
    SL6 1RF
    United Kingdom

ai_business_case.letter:
Based on the provided customer persona and the associated information, here is my detailed review and recommendations:

Customer Persona Summary:
- David is a 52-year-old council tenant living in South London.
- He is familiar with smartphone use for everyday tasks like messaging, browsing, and bill payment.
- He prefers straightforward online services that are clear and require minimal steps.
- His primary need is to request permission for small modifications (e.g., installing a kitchen or handrail) via an accessible online form that allows uploads (photos, plans).
- His main concern is delays and lack of timely updates, especially regarding the decision process, and he is cautious about avoiding tenancy breaches.

Page Content Analysis:
- The current page offers detailed information about permitted development rights and planning regulations.
- However, it appears more informational than action-oriented, which may be too complex or dense for users like David seeking straightforward application processes.
- There is no clear, simplified pathway or step-by-step guide specifically tailored to tenants wishing to request minor modifications.

Feedback & Issues:
- There is no explicit positive or negative feedback provided, but the detailed and formal nature of the content suggests it may not fully address ease of use or clarity for users seeking simple forms or quick updates.
- The absence of a dedicated, streamlined application process or status updates leads to David’s concern about delays and missed communications.

Recommendations for Improvements:
1. **Create a User-Focused Online Application Portal:**
   - Develop a simple, guided online form tailored specifically for tenants requesting minor modifications.
   - Include upload functionality for photos and plans with clear instructions.

2. **Implement Real-Time Status Tracking and Notifications:**
   - Offer automated updates via email or SMS about review progress and decisions.
   - Ensure tenants like David are not reliant solely on postal communication, reducing delays and increasing transparency.

3. **Simplify Content & Navigation:**
   - Provide a clear “Start Your Application” button prominently on the page.
   - Use plain language and visual aids to explain the process, timelines, and which modifications require permission.

4. **Clear Expectations & Timeframes:**
   - Clearly state expected response times within the application process page.
   - Set realistic expectations and reassure users about the speed of processing their requests.

**Impact of These Improvements:**
- Making the application process straightforward and transparent will significantly enhance David’s experience, reducing anxiety about delays and mistakes.
- streamlined communication will improve trust and satisfaction while decreasing administrative overhead by reducing follow-up queries.
- Overall, these enhancements will improve service efficiency, save the council money by reducing manual follow-up, and position the online platform as a trusted, user-centric gateway.

---

**Summary for the CEO:**
Investing in a simplified, transparent online application and status tracking system tailored for tenants like David will positively transform user experience. It will reduce processing times, minimize administrative costs, and foster greater trust and satisfaction among tenants—ultimately leading to a more efficient, cost-effective digital service.
